Suibhne,  Mongán & Moling:
English: The herd came up to him. ‘Dour is the deed you have  done, O herd,’ said Suibhne,‘even to slay me,  guiltless, for henceforth I cannot escape through the  hedge because of the wound you have dealt me.’ ‘If  I had known that it was you were there,’ said the herd, ‘I would not have wounded you however much you may  have injured me.’ ‘By Christ, man!’ said he, ‘I have done you no injury whatever as you think, nor  injury to anyone else on the ridge of the world since  God sent me to madness; and of small account should be  the harm to you through my being in the hedge here and  getting a little milk for God's sake from yonder woman.  And I would not trust myself with your wife nor with any  other woman for the earth and its fruits.’ ‘Christ's curse on you, O herd!’ said Moling. ‘Evil  is the deed you have done, short be your span of life  here and hell beyond, because of the deed you have  done.’ ‘There is no good to me therefrom,’ said Suibhne, ‘for your wiles have compassed me and I shall  be dead from the wound that has been dealt me.’ ‘You will get an eric for it,’ said Moling, ‘even  that you be in Heaven as long as I shall be’; and the three uttered this lay between them, that is, Suibhne, Mongan, and Moling:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The boy came on Good Friday. ‘A bad deed you have done, boy,’ said Suibhne, ‘namely, my wrongful killing, for I cannot now enjoy a peaceful life under the thin roof of golden dwellings.’ ‘If I knew who you were,’ said the boy, ‘I would not speak a great word of lamentable desire to you.’ ‘By Christ, man,’ he said, ‘it is not right for me to have a desire for one life when another man’s desire is on my deep back. God placed me in hardship and a small reward will be your redemption for my life here, and a small drop of milk you will get from God from the noble woman, and I will not turn aside from that woman, or from a learned woman on the cultivated earth.’ ‘Christ’s curse on you, boy,’ said Moling, ‘for a bad deed you have done, may long life be yours and an offering beyond on the day of the deed of the sharp deed.’ ‘There will be no death for your sake for me,’ said Suibhne, ‘for they will come with a deceitful noise around me and I will be a corpse for the golden torment.’ ‘A fine will be paid to you,’ said Moling, ‘namely, a long companionship for you in heaven,’ and they raised a lament between the three of them, namely, Suibhne, Mongán & Moling.

Suibhne greatly coveted that place and he began praising and describing it aloud; whereupon he uttered this lay:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Suibhne spent the day wandering through the boundaries of Connacht slowly and peacefully until he fell after Allt Fharannáin reached the land of Fíachrach Muaidhe; a beautiful glen emits, a beautiful stream flows greenly, shaking gently with a cold chill over all the heights and lowlands, and blessings are in its hollows, with many noble saints and true believers, and there were many slender, lofty trees with heavy, fruitful branches in that wood. English: ‘Welcome in sooth is your coming here, Suibhne’, said Moling, ‘for it is destined for you to be here and  to end your life here; to leave here your history and  adventures, and to be buried in a churchyard of  righteous folk; and I bind you,’ said Moling, ‘that  however much of Ireland you may travel each day, you  will come to me each evening so that I may write your  history.’
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: “It is fitting, gentle and welcome to come, O Suibhne,” said Moling, “that your fate is to be here, and your life to come here, your story and your wandering to be left behind, and your body to rest in a true shrine, and I weep for a fortress,” said Moling, “with great abundance every day of Ireland coming every expert to me, so that your story may be written fully.”

Roshoighedh  lá n-ann co hInnis Bó Finni i n-iarthar Chonnacht,  lá oile co hEss rocháoin Rúaidh, lá oile co Slíabh  mínáluinn Mis, lá oile go Benda biothfhúara Boirche;  gidbé díobh sin doshoighedh gach láoi nofritháiledh  a n-espurtain gach n-oidhche co Teach Moling.  Ro-ordaigh Moling proinn mbig dhó frisin ré sin,  dóigh adubairt re bhanchoig ní do bhleaghan na  mbó do thabairt dó. Muirghil a hainm-sidhe, as  í ba ben do Mhungán do mhuicidhi Moling. Ba hí  méd na proinni sin dobheiredh an bhen dó .i.  nodhingedh a sáil conuige a hadhbronn isin mbualtrach  fa coimhnesa dhí & nofágbadh a lán lemnachta ann  do Suibhne. Dothigedh-somh co faiteach furechair i  n-eatarfhásach na búailedh do ibhe an bhainne sin.
English: Thereafter during that year the madman was visiting Moling. One day he would go to Innis Bo Finne in west Connacht, another day to delightful Eas Ruaidh, another day to smooth, beautiful Sliabh Mis, another day to ever-chilly Benn Boirche, but go where he would each day, he would attend at vespers each night at Teach Moling. Moling ordered a collation for him for that hour, for he told his cook to give him some of each day's milking. Muirghil was her name; she was wife of Mongan, swineherd to Moling. This was the extent of the meal the woman used to give him: she used to thrust her heel up to her ankle in the cowdung nearest her and leave the full of it of new milk there for Suibhne. He used to come cautiously and carefully into the vacant portion of the milking yard to drink the milk.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: I took the hostages then; they spent that year coming to Moling. It was celebrated the day on which they came to Inis Bó Finni in western Connacht, a day of feasting at Ess Ruadh, a day of feasting at Slieve Mínáluinn Mis, a day of feasting to Benda Biothfhúara Boirche; may any of them who celebrated each day or spent each night at Moling’s house be blessed. Moling ordered a plentiful crop for him at that time, so that he spoke to a woman, saying she should not refuse the cows to be given to him. Muirghil was her name, and she was the wife of Mungán, whom Moling fostered. She was the portion of that crop which he inherited from the woman, that is, she did not diminish his share of it, and she left a full measure of prosperity there for Suibhne. It was then that a strange, wonderful occurrence happened in the intergrowth of the cattle-folds, concerning the milk of those cows.

Roghabh éd an búachaill ag  a chloistecht sin, & roéirigh go hobonn inníreach &  tarraidh a láimh leathga robói for alchuing astigh  & téit for amus na geilte. Tuc dono an buachaill  sadhudh don leathgha asa láimh fair, gur rosgon a  n-odhar a chíghe clé antí Suibhne, gur gabh urrainn  tríd ar mbrisedh a droma ar dhó ann. English: One night a dispute arose between Muirgil and another woman in the milking enclosure, whereupon the latter said: ‘the worse is it for you,’ said she, ‘that another  man is not more welcome to you, and yet that you do not  prefer your own husband to come to you than the madman  who is visiting you for the past year.’ The herd's sister hearkened to that; nevertheless she mentioned nothing about it until she saw Muirgil on the morrow morning going to leave the milk for Suibhne in the cowdung near the hedge at which he was. The herd's sister seeing that, came in and said to her brother: ‘You cowardly  creature, your wife is in yonder hedge with another  man,’ said she, The herd hearing that became jealous, and he rose suddenly and and and and angrily and seized a spear that was within on a rack and made for the madman. The madman's side was towards him as he was lying down eating his meal out of the cowdung. The herd made a thrust of the spear out of his hand at Suibhne and wounded him in the nipple of his left breast, so that the point went through him, breaking his back in two. (Some say that it is the point of a deer's horn the herd had placed under him in the spot where he used to take his drink out of the cowdung, that he fell on it and so met his death.)
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It happened that a transgression was committed there between Muirghil and a learned woman in the milking shed, so that the other woman said: ‘Woe to you,’ she said, ‘that you do not take another man and still do not let your own man suffice for your need of the wealth that has been given to him this year.’ The young man’s sister was angered by that, and she did not reveal to anyone who would see Muirghil in the morning going to milk the cows to Suibhne, who was close to the milking shed and accustomed to the field. Because of the young man’s sister’s observation, she came in and said to her brother: ‘Your woman is in that field with a learned man, you poor, unfortunate man,’ she said. The boy went at the sound of it, and he raged with inner fury and drew his sword halfway out of its scabbard and went out after the wealth. And thus the wealth and everything around it lay, and he was lying, tearing his groin in the milking shed. He gave the young man enough of the scabbard from his hand, so that his bones cracked on both sides of him before Suibhne, so that one could break his back in two through it. A wild, thorny bush received the boy beneath, a place where his blood was spilled in the milking shed, until he was completely still, and thus he died.

English: A gleam of reason came to him then, and he set out towards his country to entrust himself to his people and abide with them. At that time it was revealed to Ronan that Suibhne had recovered his reason and that he was going to his country to abide among his folk; whereupon Ronan said: ‘I entreat the noble, almighty King that  that persecutor may not be able to approach the church  to persecute it again as he once did, and, until his  soul has parted from his body, may there be no help or  relief to him from the vengeance which God inflicted on  him in revenge for the dishonour done to His people, so  that no other like tyrant after him may inflict outrage  or dishonour on the Lord or on His people.’
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: He came to his sense there, and set out quickly to his country to aid his people and to relieve their distress. English: God heard Ronan's prayer, for when Suibhne came to the centre of Sliabh Fuaid he stopped still there, and a strange apparition appeared to him at midnight; even trunks, headless and red, and heads without bodies, and five bristling, rough-grey heads without body or trunk among them, screaming and leaping this way and that about the road. When he came among them he heard them talking to each other, and this is what they were saying: ‘He is a  madman,’ said the first head; ‘a madman of  Ulster,’ said the second head; ‘follow him  well,’ said the third head; ‘may the pursuit be  long,’ said the fourth head; ‘until he reaches  the sea,’ said the fifth head. They rose forth together towards him. He soared aloft in front of them (passing) from thicket to thicket, and no matter how vast was the glen before him he would not touch it, but would leap from one edge of it to another, and from the summit of one hill to the summit of another.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: May God prosper you, Ronan, when suddenly came Suibhne to the middle of Slieve Fuad, and he steadied his foot there with a great increase of phantom-visions of wonder to him in the middle of the night. That is, fifty pale heads without bodies and without limbs, moving and leaping along the narrow path hither and thither. Suddenly they began to converse with each other, and it was their utterance: ‘It is a fault,’ said the first head. ‘An Ulster fault,’ said the second head. ‘It is good to be lenient,’ said the third head. ‘May leniency be long-lasting,’ said the fourth head. ‘Or may the sea be better,’ said the fifth head. He turned his loneliness towards them. Rouse yourselves! For every vein of his body and a great glen newly opened before him, he would not find it, but only a board for his body and the peaks of the hills for his support.

English: On a certain occasion Suibhne happened to be in Luachair Deaghaidh on his wild career of folly; he went thence in his course of madness until he reached Fiodh Gaibhle of clear streams and beautiful branches. In that place he remained a year and during that year his food consisted of blood-red, saffron holly-berries and dark-brown acorns, and a drink of water from the Gabhal, that is, the river from which the wood is named. At the end of that time deep grief and heavy sorrow took hold of Suibhne there because of the wretchedness of his life; whereupon he uttered this little poem:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It happened to Suibhne in the rushes of Dheadhadh to spend time with his fosterlings; he lay constantly in his royal state until the dawn of bright, gleaming hazel. Irish: Luidh iarum Suibhne gusin bhail ina raibhi  Eorann co rothoiris ar fordhorus in tighe i mbói an  ríogan cona banntracht, conadh ann adbert: ‘Sádhalp.  sin, a Eorann,’ ar sé, ‘cidh anshádhal damh-sa.’ ‘As    fíor,’ ar Eorann, ‘& táir-si asteach,’ ar sí. ‘Ní  raghatt éimh,’ ar Suibhne, ‘ar nach gabat in sluagh  imchumhang an   toighi form.’ ‘Dar liom,’ ar an  inghen, ‘nocha nferr do chiall ar gach ló dá  ttig dhuit   & ó nach áil duit anadh aguinn,’ ar sí,  ‘déna imtecht & ná háitigh   chugainn idir, dóigh is  nár linn   t'fhaicsin fón deilbh sin dona dáoinibh    atchonncatar thú fód dheilbh féin.’ ‘Truagh éimh    sin,’ air Suiblme, ‘as mairg dobheir taobh re   mnáoi  tar éis na mbriathar sin. Uair ba   maith mo  chummaoin-si ar an mnáoi   romfúagrann samhlaidh,  dóigh tucus   inn-aonló dhí trí chaoga bó & caoga  each, & dá madh é an lá romharbhus   Oilill Cédach,  rí Ua fFhaoláin, robadh   maith lé mh'fhaicsin-si’;  gonadh ann adbert annso síos:
English: Thereafter Suibhne went to the place where Eorann was and stood at the outer door of the house wherein were the queen and her womenfolk, and then he said: ‘At ease art  thou, Eorann, though ease is not for me.’ ‘True,’ said Eorann, ‘but come in,’ said she. ‘In sooth I will not,’ said Suibhne, ‘lest the army  pen me in the house.’ ‘Methinks,’ said the woman, ‘no better is your reason from day to day, and  since you do not wish to stay with us,’ said she, ‘go away and do not visit us at all, for we are ashamed  that you should be seen in that guise by people who have  seen you in your true guise.’ ‘Wretched in sooth is  that,’ said Suibhne, ‘woe to him who trusts a woman  after these words. For great was my kindness to the  woman who dismisses me thus, seeing that on one day I  gave her thrice fifty cows and fifty steeds; and if it  were the day I slew Oilill Cedach, king of the Ui  Faolain, she would have been glad to see me’; whereupon he said:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then Suibhne went to the town where was Eorann, with a request on her behalf to the house in which the queen was with her retinue; and he spoke thus: ‘Welcome, Eorann,’ said he, ‘what unwelcome thing is this to me?’ ‘It is true,’ said Eorann, ‘and come in,’ she said. ‘I will not easily go,’ said Suibhne, ‘unless the multitude will allow the shape of the house to be changed.’ ‘As I think,’ said the girl, ‘you do not have sense every day that you come, and since you do not wish to be quiet,’ she said, ‘depart and do not seek to be among us, so that our people may not see that evil shape, for they will blame you for that shape itself.’ ‘Woe is me for that,’ said Suibhne, ‘and grievous is it to side with a woman after those words. For it would be well for me to have the woman whom I formerly desired, who brought in one-half of three score cows and fifty horses, and though the day Oilill Cédach, king of Ua fFhaoláin, would have been pleased to see her’; and he spoke thus further down:

gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then Suibhne went to a town where was Eorann, with a turning on her forehead, into the house in the cow-shed of the queen with her beauty; and he spoke openly: ‘Welcome, then, O Eorann,’ said he, ‘what unwelcome thing is this to me.’ ‘It is true,’ said Eorann, ‘and come in,’ said she. ‘I will not easily go,’ said Suibhne, ‘unless the multitude will surround the house for me.’ ‘As I think,’ said the girl, ‘you do not have sense every day that you come & since you do not like to be alone,’ said she, ‘depart & do not seek to be between us, so that our people may not see that bad image for those who will recognize you as that image.’ ‘Woe to me for that,’ said Suibhne, ‘and grievous it is to side with a woman after those words. Irish: As amloid ierom boi in tech soin, edon in Craebruad Concoboir, fo intamoil tige Midhcordai. Noi n-imdodhai o ten co fraic . Triucho troiccid ind-airdiu cech airenoicch credumai boi isan  tig. Errscor di dercciuhar and. Stiall ar cabor hee ier n-ichtar & tugai slindid ier n-uachtar. Imdae Concoboir ind-airienech in tighe co stioaldoib arcait, co n-uaitnip credumai , co ligrud oir for a cendaib, co n-gemoib carrmocail intib, comma comsoloss laa & adoicc inte, gona steill aircid uasan riog co airdlius an rightighi. In n-am nobualed Concobor co flesc  rigdoi an steill, contaitis Ulaid ulie ris. Dí eimghai dec  in de erraid dec  imon imgoi sen ima cuaird.
English: On this wise was that house—viz., the Red Branch of Conchobor, after the likeness of the House of the Midcourt.3 Nine beds were in it from the fire to the wall. Thirty feet was the height of each bronze front that was in the house. Carvings of red yew were therein. It was a board [...] below, and a roof of tiles above. The bed of Conchobor was in the front of the house, with boards of silver, with pillars of bronze, with the glitter of gold on their head-pieces, and carbuncles in them, so that day and night were equally light in it, with its silver board above the king to the highest part of the royal house. Whenever Conchobor struck the board with a royal rod, all the men of Ulster were silent thereat. The twelve beds of the twelve chariot-chiefs were round about that bed.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: He was a noble champion who was in that place, a lord in Craebruad of Concobor, under the hardship of the house of Midhcordai. No escape from death for a warrior. Three times a shield is raised against every violent belief that enters the house. A harsh judgement upon them. A blow on his shield, he is not slain, and a wound on his head. Concobor entered the house with the hosts of the world, with a belief that would not fail, with a multitude before his armies, with great prosperity among them, with complete peace and welcome within, without a hostile force above the king with high right. Concobor did not boast of the strength of his shield, the men of Ulster all knew it. Two days he spent in his error, two days he was without food, until he surrounded him.

Irish: Nothelldis immorro laith galie Ulad  ac ol isan rigtoig sen & ni bid neuch dib a comcetboidh alailie. Ba han airctech  nobidis laith gailie fer n-Ulad isan ticc and-Emoin. Boi mar do    immod ceuc turcomroicc isann rigtig & de airfedaib adamroib. Arclisde & arsendtee & arcante ann, edon arclisde errid, arcantis  filid, arsendis crutirie & timpanoic.
English: Yea, the valiant warriors of the men of Ulster found place in that king's house at the drink, and no man of them would touch the other. Splendid, lavish, and beautiful were the valiant warriors of the men of Ulster in that house. There were great and numerous gatherings of every kind in that house, and wonderful pastimes. There were games and music and singing there—viz., heroes were at their feats, poets sang, harpers and players on the timpan4 struck their sounds.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Nothelldis, a maiden, was unwilling to go to the men of Ulster, and she would not drink ale with a kingly man, and she will not let a fool approach her closely. It was a great marvel, a maiden unwilling to go to the men of Ulster, to the assembly of Emain Macha. It happened, a wretched, twisted deed of kingship, and of violent deeds. A bishop and a cleric and a chanters were there, namely a bishop learned in law, chanters poets, a cleric skilled in harp and drum.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Nothelldis, a maiden, was unwilling to go to the men of Ulster, and she would not drink ale with a kingly man, and she will not let a fool approach her closely. Irish: Die mbatar 'diu Ulaid fechtus n-ann and-Emoin Machie ic ol ind iarngualai. Ced mbrothai noteged ind di lionn  cechi nonai. Ba siside  ol ngolai. Iside nofurad Ultu ulie indoensisd. Noclisdis errid Ulad ar  suainemnaib an dorus  co'roile  isan toicc and-Emhoin. Coic traigid dec ar noi  ficteb med an tige. Tri clesai  dennidis an errid .i. cles cletinech & cless ubhall & foebarcles.
English: Now, once the men of Ulster were in Emain Macha with Conchobor drinking the iern-gual (iron-coal).5 A hundred fillings of beverage went into it every evening. This was the drinking of the 'coal' that would satisfy all the men of Ulster at one time. The chariot-chiefs of Ulster were performing on ropes stretched across from door to door in the house at Emain. Fifteen feet and nine score was the size of that house. The chariot-chiefs were performing three feats—viz., the spear-feat, and the apple-feat, and the sword-edge feat.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: They say that the men of Ulster were warriors not peaceful around Emain Macha, each with a spear in his hand. A hundred were killed and a score taken captive. It was a custom to steal cattle. And they plundered the province of Ulster widely. They did not sleep around Emain Macha on the night of the battle. Five escaped that night, fleeing from the house. Three lights were seen on the plain, namely, a light of smithing and a light of baking and a light of brewing.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The men who were in the fortress of Emain Macha were warriors, and they were not idle. It is fitting that a skilled man should not be without weapons. It was a custom to have arms. And it is a necessity for Ulster to have readiness. They did not leave the fortress of Emain Macha on account of sleep or rest, nor to go outside the door for any kingly purpose. Five troops went forth at night to make sport around the house. Three lights were kindled for the troops, namely, a bright light and a light of apples and a light of embers.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The men who were in the fortress of Emain Macha were warriors, and they were not idle. It is fitting that those who are skilled should not be without practice in every art. It is a shame for a man to be unskilled. Truly, Ulster is not lacking in noble warriors. They did not neglect the fortress of Emain Macha on account of the door and the surrounding wall. Five troops went forth at night to test the house. Three weapons were brought to the fortress, namely, a shield, a spear, and a sword.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The men who were in the fortress of Emain Macha were warriors, and they were not peaceful. It is fitting that those who are skilled should not be without weapons. It was a custom to have weapons. Truly, Ulster was full of heroes. They did not allow the men of Ulster to sleep at the door of the hall in Emain. Five troops went out at night to watch the house. Three lights were kindled for the watch, namely, a bright light and a clear light and a watch-fire.

English: These are the chariot-chiefs who performed those feats—Conall the Victorious, son of Amorgen; Fergus, son of Roich      the Overbold; Loegaire the Victorious, son of Connad; Celtchar, son of Uthider; Dubthach, son of Lugaid; Cuchulaind, son of Soaldam; Scel, son of Barnene (from whom the Pass of Barnene is named), the warder of Emain Macha. From him is the saying, 'a story of Scel's,' for he was a mighty story-teller.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: These are the six champions who were in that host, namely, Conall Cernoch son of Airmirgen, Fergus son of Ross the Red, Loeccoirie Buadach son of Condoig, Celtchar son of Uthir, Dubtoch son of Lucdach, Cuculaind son of Soaldaim. Irish: Dorosce Cu Chulaind diuh ulie ocon cliuss ar aine & athlame. Ruscarsad  mna Ulod co mor  ara aine ocon clios, ar atlaime  a leme, ar febas a ergno, ar bindie a erlapra, ar coime a ghnuse, ar sercraide a dreiche. Ar batar secht mec imblesan ina rigroiscoib .i. a cethair isan dalai suil, a tri isan tsuil n-ali  ndo. Secht meoir cechtar a da coss & a secht cechtor a di laime. Batar buado imda foair. Buaid do cedus a gois noco ticced a lon laich , buaid clesomnochtai, buad mbuanfaig, buaid fidceallechtai, buaid n-airdmessai, buaid faidsene, buad crotai. Tri lochtai Con Culaind: a bieth roocc, ar ni rofasotar a rengai rodaim, ar bo moide concesdis oicc anaitnig foir, et a biith rodanai, roaloind.
English: Cuchulaind surpassed all of them at those feats for quickness and deftness. The women of Ulster loved Cuchulaind greatly for his quickness at the feats, for the nimbleness of his leap, for the excellency of his wisdom; for the sweetness of his speech, for the beauty of his face, for the loveliness of his look. For there were seven pupils in his kingly eyes, four of them in his one eye, and three of them in the other. He had seven fingers on either hand, and seven toes on either of his two feet. Many were his gifts. First, his gift of prudence until his warrior's flame appeared, the gift of feats, the gift of buanfach,6 the gift of draught-playing, the gift of calculating, the gift of sooth-saying, the gift of sense, the gift of beauty. But three faults had Cuchulaind—that he was too young (for his moustache had not grown, and all the more would unknown youths deride him), that he was too daring, that he was too beautiful.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The achievements of Cú Chulainn are told, great is his fame and his prowess. The women of Ulster magnified his fame and his valor, his leaps and his shouts, his appearance and his speech, his weapons and his boasts, his games and his skill. There were seven ways of warrior skill in his training, namely, four times a blink of the eye, and three times a blink not equal to that. Seven wounds each to two arms and seven wounds to each leg. He was always cool in battle. Victory to his heroes and may they not fall in low places, victory over enemies, lasting victory, honorable victory, noble victory, enduring victory, perfect victory. Three qualities of Cú Chulainn: to be fierce, and not to be surpassed in his valor, and to give great gifts generously to those who come to him, and to be generous, and to be just.

They were always cool in battle. Victory to heroes and their tribes, victory over every low-lying place, victory over skilled warriors, victory over lasting hatred, victory over faithful allies, victory over high kings, victory over long-lasting peace, victory over hardship. Three qualities of Con Culaind: to be fierce, and not to be surpassed in his valor, and to give great gifts to those who come to him, and to be generous, and to be noble.

Irish: Boi comairlie lia h-Ultai fodiag Conculaind, ar ruscarsod a man & a n-ingena co mor e, ar ni boi setig a fail Conculaind an tan sen. Ba si comoirli co n-irsad, setig ba  togai la  Coin Culaind de tochmarc ndo, ar bo derb leo conod  lucchaide rosoigfed  millid a n-ingenraide & foemod sercie a mban fer dia mbe  setig a coimfrestoil occo, &  ba soédh  leu mochercrai ocai , corb acobar leo ar an foáth sen toabairt mna ndo, fodég co farcbod comorbo. Ar ro fedatar is vadh bodesin nobíad a athcin .
English: The men of Ulster took counsel about Cuchulaind, for their women and maidens loved him greatly. For there was no wife with Cuchulaind at that time. This was the counsel, that they would seek a woman whom Cuchulaind might choose to woo. For they were sure that a man who had a wife to attend to him would less ravish their maidens and accept the love of their women. And, besides, they were troubled and afraid that Cuchulaind would perish early, so that for that reason they wished to give him a wife that he might leave an heir; for they knew that his re-birth would be of himself.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It was fitting for the small men of Ulster to support Cú Chulainn, for they were accustomed to his manner and the greatness of his deeds, and Cú Chulainn would not live unless he were old. It was a suitable practice to be with him, and Cú Chulainn would rise to seek a match for himself, for it was right for them to know the worth of his women and to offer service to his wives, and it was proper for young warriors to be with him, to share burdens with him in the matter of bringing women to him, for it was a difficult and burdensome task. And they said it was a bad omen that they would renew their hostility.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It was fitting for the small men of Ulster to support Cú Chulainn, for they were accustomed to his manner and his deeds as great as they were, and Cú Chulainn would not live unless he were old. It was a suitable custom, and Cú Chulainn would take a champion from them, for it was right for them to know the skill of warriors, and to offer service to the women of men who were with him, and it was right for them to provide sustenance for their fosterlings, to meet their needs on that occasion to give women to him, though they were reluctant to do so. And they said it was better to die a noble death than to renew their pledge.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: It was fitting for the small men of Ulster to support Cú Chulainn, for they were accustomed to his manner and his deeds as great as they were, and Cú Chulainn would not live unless he were old. gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: It was fitting for the small men of Ulster to provoke Cú Chulainn, for they desired his man and his women as great as he was, and they could not obtain Cú Chulainn until old age. And they said it was a bad omen that they had renewed their hostility.

Irish: Dobreta ierum Conchobor nonbur uad cevca cuiccid a n-Erinn de cungid mna de Coin Culaind dús in faigepdis indach primbaili no primdunod a n-Erinn ingen rig no roflathav no prugad de nech bud ail do togai & de tocmarc n-dou. Tancotor ulie na teachtai diblionoip & ni fuarotar ingen bud  togai la Coin Culaind de tocmarc n-do.
English: Then Conchobor sent out nine men into each province of Erinn to seek a wife for Cuchulaind, to see if they would find in any dun or in any chief place in Erinn the daughter of a king, or of a chief, or of a lord of land, whom Cuchulaind might be pleased to choose and woo. All the messengers returned that day a year gone, and had not found a maiden whom Cuchulaind chose to woo.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Conchobor sought a wife, and he went throughout Ireland to find a woman of Cú Chulainn’s lineage, so that the offspring might be a firstborn or a chief in Ireland, a daughter of a king or a noble or a free woman who would be equal to him, and for the sake of a lasting peace. Many came to meet him, and no daughter was found of Cú Chulainn’s lineage for the sake of a lasting peace.

Irish: Luid Cu Chulaind feisne  de tocmarc ingine ro-s-fitir a l-Luglochtaib Logai, edon Emer inccen Forcoild Monoch . Lod Cu Chulaind feisne & a aræ Læcc mac Riængaprai ina carput. Ass e oencarpat in sin nad foglendis dirmonnoa  na echraidie do cairptib Ulad arodene & áne  in carboid & an errid aridsuided ann.
English: Thereupon Cuchulaind himself went to woo a maiden that he knew in Luglochta Loga—viz., Emer, the daughter of Forgall the Wily. Then Cuchulaind himself and his charioteer Loeg, son of Riangabar (or Reincobir), went in his chariot. That was the one chariot which the host of the horses of the chariots of Ulster could not follow, on account of the swiftness and speed of the chariot and of who sat in it.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Cú Chulainn made an expedition to discover the portion of land fitting for a woman, namely Emer, daughter of Forgall Monach, and with the men of Lughlochta of Loga. Cú Chulainn made an expedition and his host was Læcc mac Riængaprai in his stronghold. It is said that he fortified that place so that no hostile force or raid would come to the strongholds of Ulster around it, and that the battle and the slaughter were carried out there.

Irish: Forranic Cu Chulaind in ingen ina cluichemag cona comoltaib impe. Ingenai son na m-brugad bautor im Dun Forgaill. Botar side oc foclaind  druine & decclamdai la h-Emir. Is isside ingen pas  fiu lais-sem de ingenoib Erionn do acaldoim & de tochmorc. Ar is isside congaib na sé buadha fuirre .i. buaid crotha & buad n-gothai, buaid m-bindiussai, buaid n-druine, buaid n-goisse, buaid n-gensai. At-bert Cú Chulaind acht ingen pad comadus  n-do ar aois & cruth & cinel & cles & solme, bad deuch lamdai de ingenaib Erenn nad ragad lais & na bad coimdich  n-dou do bancelib Erenn mona beth samlaid. Ar as iside oeningen congepied  na modai sen. Is airie is die tocmarc sainrud lod Cu Chulaind.
English: Then Cuchulaind found the maiden    on her playing field, with her foster-sisters around her. These were daughters of the lords of land that lived around the dun of Forgall. They were learning needle-work and fine handiwork from Emer. She was the one maiden whom he deigned to address and woo of the maidens of Erinn. For she had the six gifts—viz., the gift of beauty, the gift of voice, the gift of sweet speech, the gift of needle-work, the gift of wisdom, the gift of chastity. Cuchulaind said that no maiden should go with him but she who was his equal in age and shape and race, and skill and deftness, who was the best handworker of the maidens of Erinn, and that none was a fitting wife for him unless such were she. And as she was the one maiden that fulfilled all those conditions, Cuchulaind went to woo her above all.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Concerning Cu Chulaind and the daughter he played with in his youth. Daughters were sought for the champions in Dun Forgaill. A pledge was made to declare judgment and to proclaim it to the Emir. It was by her that a man would be judged among the daughters of Ireland for excellence and for prowess. And it was by her that the five tokens of heroism were given – the token of bravery, the token of nobility, the token of hospitality, the token of judgment, the token of eloquence, the token of lineage. Cu Chulaind then spoke, but a daughter who was equal to him in age and form and race and skill and appearance was not found, so that he tested all the daughters of Ireland and none surpassed her nor was anyone comparable to her in the territories of Ireland, not even a little. And from her were conceived the virtues of the world. And therefore is that prowess renowned in the story of Cu Chulaind.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Concerning Cu Chulaind and the daughter he played with in his youth. Daughters were sought for the champions in Dun Forgaill. And from her were conceived the seeds of wisdom. And it is from her that this adventure is renowned in the story of Cu Chulaind.

Irish: Lvid ierum Cu Chulaind co h-airmb i m-boi Scatoig. Do bir a di coiss for da m-bordaib  in clep cliss & nochtaiss in cloideb & do bretha  a rinn fo comair a cride & ispert: ‘Bas h-vassut!’ ol se. ‘To trí drinnroisc dait ’, al si, ‘fep tissed liat anail .’ ‘Gebthar!’ ol Cu Culaind. Fo naisscid uirri iarum. Is ed airmid araili slechta annso, co ruc Cv Culaind Scathaig laiss issan tracht & co comranic frie ann & co ro cotail  ina farrud, conid annsidie ro cachain indí seu oc a taircetul  gach neich  aridbíad, co n-epert: ‘Focen, a scithbvaidnige’ & rl. Acht ni h-airmithir iarsan slicht so sen olceno .
English: Then Cuchulaind went to the place where Scathach was. He placed his two feet on the two edges of the basket of the cless, and bared his sword, and put its point to her heart, saying: ‘Death over thee!’ said he, ‘Thy three wishes from me!’ said she, viz., ‘thy three wishes as thou canst utter them in one breath,’ ‘They shall be taken,’ said Cuchulaind. He then pledged her. Other versions say here Cuchulaind took Scathach with him to the shore, and lay with her there, and slept with her, and that it was then that she sang this, prophesying to him everything that would befal him, saying: ‘Welcome, oh [...]’ etc. But that is not told thus after this account.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Loud was the cry of Cú Chulainn when he struck the cow Scáthach. He carried her and her calves over two boards, a grey cloak and a dark mantle, and a judgement he made under the shadow of his heart and spoke: ‘Death to the wretched!’ said he. ‘Three drops of venom to you,’ she said, ‘have poisoned your breath.’ ‘Enough!’ said Cú Chulainn. Under a cloud of fury he was then. It was another cruel slaughter here, so rushed Cú Chulainn at Scáthach’s host with that attack and with fierce conflict among them and with great skill in his attack, until he caused every man to fall around him, and he spoke: ‘Burn, you wretched ones!’ and so on. But it is not remembered now that such a deed was ever evil.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Loud was the cry of Cú Chulainn when he struck the cow Scáthach. He carried her and her calves over two boards, a grey cloak and a dark mantle, and a judgement he made under the shadow of his heart and spoke: ‘Death to the unskillful!’ said he. ‘Three drops of poison for you,’ she said, ‘have touched your breath.’ ‘Enough!’ said Cú Chulainn. Under a cloud of fury he was then. It was another sharp wound here, so that Cú Chulainn struck Scáthach’s side with it and battled with her and was well-content in his fighting, until he caused every limb of her to be broken, so that he spoke: ‘Burn, you wicked woman!’ and so on. But he did not strike another wound so evil as that one.

Irish: Foidis Uathach la Coin Culaind & nu-s-forcedlæ Scáthach immon milti  . Isan aimseir sin tra  boi seom la Scathaich & a muinterus h-Uathqu a h-ingene, is and diluid aroili fer aumræ boi la Mumain .i. Lugaid mac Nois mac Alamaic in ri soinemail, coicceli (.i. comalta) Con Cvlaind. Dilligh  indiar & dá errig  deucc imbi  do errigaib  na Muman di tochmarc da n-ingeun dec Níaidhfér maic Rusa.   Arnassa sen di feraib vili remib-seum. An tan iarum ro caula som Forcall Monuch indi sein, forrumai  do Teumraig & ispert fri Lugaid boi oca-seum ind-oentumæ ingen is dech bai ind-Eriu etir cruth & genus & lamdæ. Aspert Lugaid ba maith laiss inn sen. Arnaiss iarum Forculd a ingeun dind rig & da ingin deuc na di m-briugad n-decc olceno uá Breghu den di errig  n-déac botar aræn la Lugaid.
English: Uathach then slept with Cuchulaind, and Scathach taught him skill of arms. During the time that he was with Scathach and the husband of Uathach, her daughter, a certain famous man who lived in Munster, viz. Lugaid, son of Nos, son of Alamac, the renowned king, and fosterbrother of Cuchulaind, went eastward with twelve chariot-chiefs of the high kings of Munster, to woo twelve maidens of the men of Mac Rossa. All these were betrothed to men before. When Forgall the Wily heard this, he went to Tara, and said to Lugaid that the best maiden in Erinn, both in shape and chastity and handiwork, was living with him unmarried. Lugaid said it pleased him well. Then Forgall betrothed the maiden to the king; and the twelve daughters of the twelve lords of land in Bray besides to the twelve under-kings that were together with Lugaid.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Uathach went to the peak of Culaind and Scáthach eagerly welcomed the noble warrior. It was then he spent a year with Scáthach and her household, and Uathach’s foster-son, Lugaid son of Nois son of Alamaic, the king, was a champion of Cú Chulaind. He demanded two hostages and two portions of land from the men of Munster as a bride-price for the two daughters of Níaidhfér son of Rus. He was then a fierce man among the valiant. After that, Forcall of the Monuch spoke to him, promising him to the women of Temair and hinting to Lugaid about the beautiful daughter who was in Ireland, of perfect form and lineage and beauty. Lugaid thought it was good to hear that. Forcall then offered the king’s daughter and two portions of land from the two thirds that belonged to the territory of Breghu, as a reward for Lugaid.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Uathach went to the peak of Culaind and Scáthach eagerly welcomed the noble warrior. It was then he spent time with Scáthach and her household, and Uathach’s foster-son, Lugaid son of Nois son of Alamaic, the king who possessed the five provinces (i.e. territories) of Connacht. He diligently sought two hostages from the men of Munster as a token for Scáthach’s two daughters of Niafér son of Rus. He demanded this of those men willingly. Lugaid thought it was good to hear this. Forcall then gave the maiden to the king and two maidens from the two lesser provinces of Breghu, as a pledge to Lugaid.

Irish: Dotæt an ri den banfeis ar oen lia Forgauld dia dunat. An tan iarum de brethau Emiur di Lucctith dochum ind ionaid a m-bai oc  s-suidiu for a laim, digabaid si a dá n-gruad. ‘For fior h'oinich & h'anmo daum!’ ol si & adamair  ba Cu Culaind carustar & for a greiss bui & ba coll oinigh cibe do berud isse. Ni forlamair iarum indti Lugaid feis la h-Emir ar omon Con Culaind & imdosæi afritesse dia tigh.
English: The king went along with Forgall to his dun for the wedding. When now Emer was brought to Lugaid to sit by his side, she took in both her hands his two cheeks, and laid it on the troth of his honour and his life and confessed that it was Cuchulaind she loved, that Forgall was against it, that it was loss of honour for anyone to take her to wife. Then, from fear of Cuchulaind,    Lugaid did not dare to sleep with Emer, and he returned home again.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The king gave the woman a kiss on one lip. May God prosper you. Then, of the brothers of Emur, Lucctith went to the place where they were sitting for a game, and she separated them with two hands. ‘For true love and a soul for both!’ she cried, and she stirred up Cu Culaind’s affection, and for his grace she was beautiful and every man desired her. Afterwards Lugaid went to Emur’s house, alone with Con Culaind, and a strange story came to the house.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The king gave the woman a kiss on one lip. May God prosper you. Then the brothers of Emur of Lucctith came to the place where they were sitting for a game, and they separated him from his two thighs. ‘For true love and a true soul!’ he cried and lamented, for Cú Chulainn was beloved and for his beauty he was renowned, and every man who saw him loved him. Then Lugaid did not leave that place with Emur on the name of Cú Chulainn and a story was told about his house.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The king gave the woman a kiss on one lip. May God prosper you. Then the brothers of Emur of Lucctith came to the place where they were sitting for a game, and they separated him from his two thighs. ‘For true love and a true soul!’ he cried and lamented, for Cú Chulainn was beloved and for his grace he was bright and every boast he made was true. Afterwards Lugaid came to Emur on the occasion of Con Chulainn and a strange story came to his house.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The king gave the woman a kiss on one lip. May God prosper you. Then the brothers of Emur of Lucctith came to the place where they were sitting, and they separated him from his two companions. ‘For a true oath and a soul for God!’ he cried, and he lamented that Cú Chulainn was beloved and for his grace he was bright, and every oath he uttered was true. Then Lugaid did not leave that place with Emur on the name of Cú Chulainn and he departed swiftly from the house.

Irish: Bai cauth for Scathaig dno issan aimsir sene fria tuatai ali & is forra s-side ba banflaith Aifi. Ro tinoilset iarum  cechtarda líno do tabairt in cauthæ, co recht (.i. docenglad) lia Scathaig Cú Chulaind & imdisai ifritesse & debreuth deug suain n-do riam ar na tessed isan cath, ar na rissed ní do ann. Ar choimainmche  do gnith se sein. Do fochrasstar  'diu ellam inti Cv Chulaind assa cotlad iar n-var fochétoir; ar a m-ba mithesse ceteourai n-var fichet do neuc ali din digh svain i cotlad, ba h-oenúar n-dossom innsin.
English: Scathach was at that time carrying on war against other tribes over which the Princess Aife was ruling. Then the two hosts assembled to fight. Cuchulaind was put in bonds by Scathach, and a sleeping potion had been given him before, that he might not go to the battle lest anything should happen to him there. As a precaution (?) she did this. Then forthwith out of his sleep started Cuchulaind after an hour. While anybody else would have slept twenty-four hours with this sleeping potion, it was only one hour for him.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It was fitting for Scathach to teach her skills at that time, freely to warriors both great and small, and it was for this reason that Banflaith, daughter of Aife, was with her. She had requested a quarter of the teaching to be given to the captive, so that Scathach and Cú Chulainn might be equal; and she wished for fairness and a just share for her son, who had never been in battle or war. It was by this agreement that the deed was done. She had weakened Cú Chulainn’s mind with sleep after much exertion; and it was better for him to be victorious than to be defeated, for one man is enough to tell the tale.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It was fitting for Scathach to teach her skills at that time, freely to all her foster-children, and it was for this reason that Banflaith, daughter of Aife, was with her. She had summoned four score youths to receive instruction in warfare, so that the valor of Scathach and Cú Chulainn might be tested, and to see their prowess and the strength of their warriors in battle, for there was no contest before. It is well known what deed he did. He surpassed all others in skill; for his strength was such that he could perform the work of fifty men, and it was a wonder to see him do it.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: It was fitting for Scathach to teach her skills at that time to warriors gladly, and it was for that reason she was a skilled woman, Aifi. She had previously tested four score youths to give the skill, so that the valor of Scathach and Cú Chulaind was known, and their bravery and the deeds of their servants were never before seen in battle, nor were their weaknesses. It is for the sake of that deed that this is said. She exhausted all her strength in Cú Chulaind until he slept after much exertion; and it would be better to have fifty weak men than one skilled man in that sleep, for it was a great wonder to see it.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: It was fitting for Scathach to teach her skills at that time, freely to warriors both great and small, and it was for this reason that Banflaith, daughter of Aife, was with her. She had requested a quarter of the teaching to be given to the captive, so that Scathach and Cú Chulainn might be equal; and she wished to test and prove the worth of a man who had never been in battle, or who had been but little. And it is by this deed that her action is known. She had undermined all the skill of Cú Chulainn, so that he was less skilled after than he had been before; and it was a great loss for every man who was skilled in warfare, for one man was diminished by it.

Irish: Lvid iarum la da mac Scathqu din cath ar cinn trí mac Ilsvanaigh .i. Cuar & Cet & Cruifne iat side trí milid Aifi. Arossanaic sim a tríar a oenur & deceurtar  laiss. Bai dal in catho arnauharuch & do toegat  ín t-slvaig cechtardai co m-batar in da n-idhnæ drech ria dreich. Lotar 'div trí mic Esse Enchinne & Cirí & Birí & Bailcne, trí milid aili di Aiffe & forfvacarsad  comlonn for dá mac Scatqui. Do lotar side for an ted cliss. Fo ceurd Scathach essnaid dissvidi, ar ní fitir cid no piad de. Aill on bad  bith cen in tress feur la da mauc Scathce frisan triar amne & dono ba h-omon  le Aiffe in bainfendig, fodeug is side ba h-annsom bvi issan doman. Lvid 'div Cu Chulaind fria a da mac-si & nu-s-leublaing for an tet & immacomarnic  n-do-ssom friu i tríur & beuhsatar lais.
English: He then went with the two sons of Scathach against the three sons of Ilsuanach, viz., Cuar and Cett and Cruife, three warriors of Aife's. Alone he met them all three, and they fell by him. There was a meeting in battle on the next morning, and both hosts went until the two arrays were face to face. Then went the three sons of Esse Enchinde, viz. Cire and Bire and Blaicne, three other warriors of Aife, and began combat against the two sons of Scathach. They went on the path of feats. Scathach uttered a sigh at this, for she knew not what would come of it, first, as there was no third man with her two sons against those three and then she was afraid of Aife, because, she was the hardest woman-warrior in the world. Then Cuchulaind went up to her two sons, and sprang on the path, and met them all three, and they fell by him.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: There is a story about them, namely, the sons of Scathach who waged war on the three sons of Ilsvanaigh, namely, Cuar and Cet and Cruifne, who were three warriors of the tribe of Aifi. Aressanaic overcame them with one attack and left twenty slain. Great was the battle that was fought, and the slaughter was such that the two hosts were broken by each other. Lotar divided the three sons of Esse Enchinne and Ciri and Biri and Bailcne, three warriors of the tribe of Aifi, and they plundered a great spoil for the two sons of Scathach. Lotar also took for himself a great treasure. Under the protection of Scathach, they prospered, for there was no lack of food or drink. It is said that life is better without hardship for the two sons of Scathach, for they were three times as strong and were always at odds with the tribe of Aifi, who were fierce and warlike. There is a story about Cu Chulaind with their sons, and he did not refuse to fight for them, and he made a covenant with them, and they were victorious.

Irish: Focraiss Aiffe comlonn  for Scathaig. Lott Cv  Cvlaind ar cinn Aeiffi & iermofoacht qid ba moam serc  bui  aicti riam. Aspert Scathach: ‘Iss ed ba moom serc lei ,’ ol si ‘a dá h-euch & i carpat . ’ Dilotar didiu for in tet cliss Cv Chulaind & Aiffi & fersaid cumleng  fair. Docombai (.i. brissid ) iarum Aiffi a h-airm  for Coin Cvlaind, co na pa sia dornd a claideb. Is ann asmpert  Cu Culaind: ‘Aill amai!’ ol sé, ‘derochair arau  Aiffi & a da h-euch carpait  fon gleun conidnapatar  ulie.’ Decid Aiffi lassotain. Fossdicet Cu Culaind la sotain & gabthus foa dib cichib & dompert  tarsnai amail assclaing , conatulaid gona slvagu bodein Cú Culaind leis h-i , gonratustar  a beim fri talmain dii & do beurt claideb urnocht vasti. Asbert Aifi: ‘Anmoin in anmain, a Cu Chulaind!’ al si. ‘Mo trí drinnrvisc  dam-sa!’ ol se. ‘Ro-t-biad amoil  no tistais lat anail’, or si. ‘It e tri drinnroisc ’, ol sé, ‘giallnæi do Scathaig cen nach frithorgain fria iarum, mvinterus frium d'adaig ar belaibh di dunaicch fen & co rucai mac dam.’ ‘Atmaur-sa amlaid ’, ol si. ‘Digentar airiut  foan innus sin.’ Lvid didiu Cu Chulaind la h-Aeifi & fæidiss  lee in aidqi sin. Asbert  iarum inti Aiffe ba torruch & mac nu-s-berad . ‘Cvirfed-sai 'div dia secht m-bliadan co h-Érin h-e’, ol si, ‘& facaib-se ainm do.’ Facbaiss Cv Chulaind dornnaisc n-oir n-do & ispert frie gon tissad dia cvingid-seum co h-Érinn in tan bvd lan in dornnaisc dia meor & ispert co m-bad é a ainm do bretha n-dov Conlui & aspert frie nacha slonnad  d'oinfir & nacha m-beurad oinfer dia sligid & na rodobad  comlonn ainfir.
English: Aife challenged Scathach to combat, Cuchulaind went up before Aife, and asked what it was she loved most. Scathach said: ‘What she loves most,’ said she, ‘is her two horses and her chariot and her charioteer.’ Cuchulaind and Aife went on the path of feats and began combat there. Then Aife shattered Cuchulaind's weapon so that his sword was no longer than his fist ‘Ah,’ cried he, ‘the charioteer of Aife and her two horses and her chariot have fallen down in the glen, and have all perished!’ At that Aife looked up. Then Cuchulaind approached her, seized her at her two breasts, took her on his back like a shoulder-load, and carried her with him to his own host. Then he threw her from him to the ground, and placed his bare sword over him. And Aife said: ‘Life for life, oh Cuchulaind!’ ‘My three wishes to me!’ said he, ‘Thou shalt have them, as they come with thy breath,’ said she. ‘These are my three wishes,’ said he, ‘thou to give hostage to Scathach, without ever afterwards opposing her, thou to be with me this night before thy dun, and to bear me a son,’ ‘I promise it all thus,’ said she. It was done in that wise.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Scathach challenged Cú Chulaind to a contest with Aiffi. Cú Chulaind struck Aiffi with his spear, but she did not fall. Scathach said, “It is little love she has for you,” and she healed Aiffi’s two wounds. Cú Chulaind then struck Aiffi again with his spear, and she fell to the ground. Cú Chulaind cried out, “Mine now!” and he tore at Aiffi’s two wounds until the blood flowed, attempting to deprive Cú Chulaind of his strength. Aiffi said, “My soul to you, Cú Chulaind!” and she offered him her three magical skins. He said, “They were always yours, or you will not live to breathe,” and he said, “These are three magical skins, given to Scathach so that no one would attack her, and they will protect your foster-son from every hardship.” She said, “I give them to you, and you will find use for them.” Cú Chulaind then took Aiffi’s hand and tested the power of that gift. Afterwards, Aiffi said she was pregnant and with a son who would be unmatched. “He will rule Ireland for seven years,” she said, “and you will know his name.” Cú Chulaind saw a golden chain and asked what it was, and was told it was a chain to bind him to Ireland until the end of his days, and that his name would be known to every judge, and that no woman would refuse him passage or obstruct his path, nor would anyone challenge his right.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Scathach challenged Cú Chulaind to a contest with Aiffi. Cú Chulaind struck Aiffi with his spear, but she did not fall. Scathach said, “It is little love she has for you,” and she healed Aiffi’s two wounds. Cú Chulaind then struck Aiffi again with his spear, and she fell to the ground. Cú Chulaind said, “Mine now!” and he tore at Aiffi’s two wounds, causing great pain. Aiffi cried out. Cú Chulaind then seized her by the hair and threw her across his back, attempting to break her spine. Aiffi said, “My soul is in your hands, Cú Chulaind!” and he replied, “I will not release you until you give me three kisses.” He said, “These are the three kisses,” and he demanded that she not speak of it to Scathach, nor reveal their encounter to anyone, nor tell her son of it. She agreed. He then released Aiffi and went with her to the ford. Aiffi then declared she was pregnant and with a son who would be unmatched. She said, “He will rule Ireland for seven years,” and “You will know his name.” Cú Chulaind then demanded a pledge from her, and she promised that he would have dominion over Ireland as long as she lived, and that she would reveal his name to no one, and that she would not allow anyone to interfere with his path, nor would she reveal his lineage. She agreed. He then left Aiffi and went on his way. She later declared that she bore a son who was destined to be great.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Scathach challenged Cú Chulaind to a contest with Aiffi. Cú Chulaind struck Aiffi with his spear, but she did not fall. Afterward, Aiffi said she was pregnant and would bear a son who would be no ordinary man. She prophesied that he would spend seven years in Ireland and that she would name him. Cú Chulaind promised to give her a golden torque and to ensure his name would be known throughout Ireland, and that he would establish laws and judgments. gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Scathach challenged Aife to a contest for Cú Chulaind. Cú Chulaind and Cvlaind were on Aife’s side, and a great love arose between them. Scathach said, ‘It is better to love her,’ and she said, ‘with her two breasts and her beauty.’ Cú Chulaind and Aife then made a pact. Aife broke her promise to Cú Chulaind, so that she could wound him with her sword. Then Cú Chulaind said, ‘It is wrong!’ and he said, ‘you have deceived Aife and her two beautiful breasts under her cloak,’ and he struck her. Aife then retreated. Cú Chulaind pursued her and seized her two cheeks and pushed her across the water, attempting to weaken Cú Chulaind with her magic, but she could not harm him, and she threw her sword far away. Aife said, ‘My soul, Cú Chulaind!’ and she said, ‘My three kisses for you!’ He said, ‘You will not be free or safe until you give me your three kisses,’ and he said, ‘they are three kisses for Scathach, so that you will not betray her again, and a winter’s journey for you to the islands of the fierce, and with the son you bear.’ ‘I agree to that,’ she said, ‘you will find me for this.’ Cú Chulaind then went with Aife and completed that deed. Afterwards, Aife said she was pregnant and with a son who would be famous. ‘He will rule Ireland for seven years,’ she said, ‘and you will know his name.’ Cú Chulaind accepted a pledge from her, and said he would not allow him to come to Ireland until the day he would need his help, and he said he would know his name by his judgment in a dispute, and he said she would not refuse him hospitality or hinder him on his path, nor would she conceal his birth.

Irish: Ataninntai Cv Cvlaind coa muindtir n-iarum fessne & issed tanic, for an tét cétnoi. Co farnoic sentvinn tuathcæich for a cinn  for an teid. Atbert som  fris-som ara forchaine  ar na beth for a cinn iersan teid. Aspert som nad mbvie occo conar diroisevd  acht fon  ald mor ro boi foi. Aidchisi fris an conair do legivd  n-dii. Do lec seum din tet acht giuil a  ladair  aire namaa. A n-dolvid si vassæ fornessæ a ordain di cor den tetd dia chor foan ald. Airiges som dno indni sen & fo cerd ich n-errid n-de svass doridesse & benaiss  a cend din caillig. Ba si sen mathair na tri caurad n-degeunach doceurthur les-sum .i. Ess  Enchine, & fodeicc a admillte-sevm tanaic ar a cind. Do loutar iarum in t-slvaig la Scathaig dia crichaibh feisne & dibrethai gellnai o Aiffi le & anais Cu Culaind denas  taithslainti i fuss.
English: Thereupon Cuchulaind returned back again to his own people and came along the same road. He met an old woman on the road who was blind of her left eye. She asked him to beware and not be on the road before her. He said there was no room for a footing for him save on the cliff of the sea which was beneath him. She besought him to leave the road to her. Then he left the road except that his toes clung to it. When she passed over him she hit his great toe to throw him off the path down the cliff. He noticed it and leapt the hero's salmon-leap up again, and struck the woman's head off. She was the mother of the three last warriors that had fallen by him, viz., Esse Enchinde, and in order to destroy him had come to meet him.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: At Cuailnge were hounds with a western people, skilled and it was thus they came, for the hosting of the hundred. With what skill did the tribesmen make their heads for the hosting? Atbert was a free man, a noble warrior, over the men for their heads in the hosting. Aspert was not wont to seek strife except by the great sea that was before him. He sought the path to be given to him by God. He did not deem it good to be without his warriors, lest his name be forgotten. Let those vassals be ready to obey his command for the sake of the hosting, for the sake of the great age that was. He recounted the signs and the deeds that were not hidden, and spoke of the benefits and blessings of his lineage. She was the mother of three hundred noble warriors, skilled in all arts, namely Ess Enchine, and she fostered her fosterlings on her knee. Afterwards the host went to Sluaige with Scathach for the sake of skill and to test the young warriors from Aífe and the feats of Cú Chulainn were a delight to all.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: At Cuailnge were complaints about the men of the west, and it was thus it happened, for the sake of a hundred cows. With what skill did the men of Ulster act for their heads for that deed? Atbert was a free man who often spoke of the things for their heads, yesterday. Aspert said that it was not right for him to attempt a prophecy except by the great old age that was in him. He sought the way to be given to him by God. He did not value a single cow except for the sake of his people’s honour. Let the vassals of the forest obey your command to give a cow for every year of old age. It is said that he had no daughter who was a skilled woman, and who would not be a vassal to a skilled woman and would not lose her honour. She was the mother of three hundred noble warriors, a learned woman, namely Ess Enchine, and she accepted her share. Afterwards the host went to Sluaige with Scathach for the sake of training and to obtain knowledge from Aifi and the deeds of Cu Chulainn were a source of glory in battle.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: At Cuailnge were complaints about the men of the west, and it was thus it happened, for the sake of a hundred cows. With what skill did the men of Ulster act for their heads for that deed? Atbert was a free man, and his forebears were on those terms for their heads in former times. Aspert was not wont to seek counsel except from the great elder who was alive then. He sought the way to be given to him by God. He did not deem it good to speak except to give heed to his words. Let not his vassals forget his command to give a share of the land for the sake of God. It is said that he had no daughter who was not honoured, and blessed was her offspring. She was the mother of three score and seventeen noble scholars, namely, Ess Enchine, and she received her admission thus on her behalf. Afterwards the host went to Sluaige in Scathach’s land for the sake of training and to learn the arts from Aifi and the feats of Cú Chulainn were a source of glory in battle.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: At Cuailnge were hounds with a western people, skilled and it was thus they came, for the hosting of the hundred. Irish: O ru-s-scaich iarum de Coin Culaind lanfoglaim in milti do denum la Scathaig etir uballclius & torandcless & foebarcless & foencless & cles cletinech & tetcless & foerclius  & corpcless & cless caid & ich n-errid & corndeliud  & gai bulgai & bai braisse & rothcless & otharcless & cless for analai & brud n-geunai (no gemi ) & sian curad & bem fo commus & taithbeim & fodbeim & dreim fri fogaist co n-dirged creiti for a rinn & carbad serrdhai & fonaidm niadh for rinnib sleg, tainic timgairi do tiachtain dia toig  fesin iarum & timnaiss celiubrad & aspert iarvm Scathach fris iarsen inni arudbai dia forcenn & ro cachain n-do tria h-imus forhossnai, conad ann ispert na priathru sai n-dou.
English: After the full lore of his soldierly arts with Scathach had passed for Cuchulaind—as well as the apple-feat, the thunder-feat, the blade-feat, the foen-feat, and the spear-feat, the rope-feat, the body-feat, the cat's feat, the salmon-feat of a chariot-chief, the throw of the staff, the jump over [...], the whirl of a brave chariot-chief, the spear of the bellows,37 the boi of swiftness, the wheel-feat, the othar-feat, the breath-feat, the brud geme, the hero's whoop, the blow [...], the counter-blow, running up a lance and righting the body on its point, the scythe-chariot, and the hero's twisting round the    points of spears,—then came a message to him to return to his own land, and he took leave. Then Scathach told him what would befal him in the future, and sang to him in the seer's large shining ken,38 and spake these words:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: O, a scattering afterwards of the forces of Cooley, a complete seizure of the battle for the sake of Scathach, between skill and prowess and bravery and generosity and glory and excellence and bodies of heroes and a host of warriors and a great multitude and a fierce attack and a noble victory and a host of youths and a boastful cry and a swift pursuit and a lamentable destruction for her sake, and a fierce slaughter and a painful cry, came Timgair to seek a boon from her, for he knew her skill, and a promise of training and a report afterwards of Scathach concerning her teaching within, a great reward for her fostering and a great abundance for those three times she surpassed, how then is there a test for those who do not know.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: O, a scattering afterwards of the forces of Cooley, a complete seizure of the battle for the sake of Scathach, between skill and prowess and bravery and generosity and glory and cleverness and strength and bodies and wealth and need and error and abundance and cattle and cattle-raids and ruin and other skills and a multitude of cures and healing and sleep and dreams with a fostering until the completion of a judgement for her sake, and deeds of heroes and a voice of strength for her people and a sharp sword, came Taimgair to seek a boon from her, himself afterwards and a promise of training, and a request from Scathach for her teaching within her dwelling, a foretelling of victory and a great boasting not through weakness for foresight, how then is a secret revealed without a price, she said.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: O, a skillful outburst after the heroism of Cú Chulainn, a complete taking of the warrior’s portion from Scathach, between skill and prowess and strength and valor and glory and bright fame and a noble body and a glorious deed and a pure spear, and a great host and a noble agreement and a swift shield and a generous offering and a glorious battle-cry and a silent prayer and a skillful hosting, until the end of judgment for her sake, and a hard battle and a noble deed of strength for her people, a spear came to meet him by his own will, and a promise of heavenly glory, and a request after Scathach for her teaching within her dwelling, a noble reward for her foresight and she was worthy of all that was done for her, how is it known that the branches of the world are not with us?
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: O, a cry for battle afterwards from the peak of Cooley, a complete seizure of the warrior-host for the sake of Scathach, between valleys and ridges and hollows and meadows and a grey stone-place and a rounded hillock and a hollow body and a bright peak and a hard branch, and it is not permitted, and a full gathering, and a red crowd and a speckled cloak and a wheel-less chariot and a vast dwelling and a peak for birds and a secret place (or a gem), and a wise healing and a poisonous sleep and a journey and a dwelling and a dream concerning prophecy until the final judgement for its edge, and a hard chariot and a voice of hunting for its edges of spears, came Taimgar to seek God himself afterwards and the pledges of a noble woman, and a lamentation afterwards for Scathach for her skill in it, a red dawn for her, and she was accustomed to it through the three great paths before us, how is it now, a lamentation for the women who are not free.

Irish: Ticc an ingen den dunad  & ad-fet dia h-athair a      scel n-uli. Tic Cu Culaind den dunad  ierum amail cech n-óigid. Feraid failti fris ierum Conoll & Lægairi. Moidid sochaide issan dun  marbad na Fomóre dano, acht nirro creid and ingen doib. Mosronad  fothraccud don  rig & do breta cach ar uair chuice. Tainic Cu Culaind dno cumai caich & ro rad  an ingen aithne fair. ‘Do-m-beur an ingen dit ’, for Ruad, ‘& icfad fein a tinnscrai.’ ‘Nato’, ol Cu Chulaind. ‘Ticceud dia bliadna imm deugaid-se co h-Érinn mad ail n-di & fogepai messe an.’
English: The maiden came to the dun and told her father the whole story. Thereafter Cuchulaind came to the dun like every other guest. Then Conall and Loegaire welcomed him. Many in the dun boasted of having killed the Fomori, but the maiden did not believe them. A bath was then prepared by the king, and each one was brought to her separately. Then Cuchulaind came like everybody else, and the maiden recognized him, ‘I shall give the maiden to thee.’ said Ruad, ‘and I shall pay her wedding-gift myself.’ ‘Not so,’ said Cuchulaind. ‘Let her come this day year to Erinn after me, if it be pleasant to her, and she will find me there.’
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The maiden was taken from the fortress, and a pledge was made by her father regarding her news. Cú Chulainn took the maiden from the fortress, a pearl like every young girl. Welcome was offered to him by Conall and Lægair. A great battle was fought in the fortress, the slaying of the Fomorians there, but they did not believe the maiden’s words. A skilled poet was sent to the king and his assembly every time towards him. Cú Chulainn came to him, meeting everyone, and the maiden revealed her name. ‘Do not give the maiden to him,’ said Ruad, ‘and I myself will suffer for it.’ ‘Never,’ said Cú Chulainn. ‘She will spend two years and ten in Ireland, and I will watch over her.’

English: Now Cuchulaind killed one hundred on each ford from Ath Scennmend at Ollbine to the Boyne of Bray, and he fulfilled all the deeds that he had vowed to the maiden, and he came safely out of it, and reached Emain Macha towards the darkness of that night. English: A council was held by the men of Ulster about this affair. English: The Túatha Dé came with a great fleet to Ireland to take it by force from the Fir Bolg. Upon reaching the territory of Corcu Belgatan (which is Conmaicne Mara today), they at once burned their boats so that they would not think of fleeing to them. The smoke and the mist which came from the ships filled the land and the air which was near them. For that reason it has been thought that they arrived in clouds of mist.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The men of Tuatha Dé Danann came at dawn on a great hosting to oppose the taking of Ireland by the Fir Bolg. They pitched their tents under the ridge after the breaking of the peak of Corcu Belgatan (i.e., the Conmaicne Mara of today), where their watch was on the hollow of the cock. Then the gods and the men who came with them made a covenant with the tribes and the nobles to be at peace with them. From that, they demanded their tribute and their hostages.

English: One day one of their women, Ériu the daughter of Delbáeth, was looking at the sea and the land from the house of Máeth Scéni; and she saw the sea as perfectly calm as if it were a level board. English: ‘You will not remain ignorant of that,’ he said. ‘Elatha mac Delbaith, king of the Fomoire, has come to you. English: Now the Dagda was unhappy at the work, and in the house he used to meet an idle blind man named Cridenbél, whose mouth grew out of his chest. English: In that wise he remained in Glen Bolcain until at a certain time he raised himself up (into the air) and went to Cluain Cille on the border of Tir Conaill and Tir Boghaine. He went then to the brink of the well where he had for food that night watercress and water. Thereafter he went into the old tree of the church. The erenach of the church was Faibhlen of the family of Brughach, son of Deaghadh. That night there came an exceeding great storm so. that the extent of the night's misery affected Suibhne greatly, and he said: ‘Sad indeed is it that I was not  slain at Magh Rath rather than that I should encounter  this hardship’; whereupon he uttered this lay:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: I spent that time in Glan Bolcáin until I roasted my face there with the cold of Cluan Cilli and the boundaries of Tir Conaill & Tir Boghaine. Then it rained heavily with hail and water that night. It went afterwards to the top of the church. And it was most fitting in that church, Fáibhlen for the people of Brugha, the sons of Deaghaidh, and a great grey darkness came that night, so that Suibhne was greatly disturbed by the gloom of that night and he exclaimed: ‘Alas,’ he said, ‘that Muigh Rath was not killed to relieve me of this hardship’; until the song here below was sung to exhaustion.

Irish: Táinic Suibhne roimhe iarumh co riacht an  chill ag Snámh dhá Én for Sionainn, dian comainm  Cluain Boirenn an tan sa; día na haoine dídine an  tsainridh ráinic-siumh annsin. As ann iarumh bádar  cléirigh na cille ag dénamh an uird nóna ocus mná ag  túargain lín & ben ag breth leinb. ‘Nior bhó cóir  éimh,’ ar Suibhne, ‘don mhnáoi aoine an   Choimdedh  do mhilledh. English: So Suibhne fared forth until he reached the church at Snamh dha En on the Shannon, which is now called Cluain Boirenn; he arrived there on a Friday, to speak precisely. The clerics of the church were then fulfilling the office of nones; women were beating flax, and one was giving birth to a child. ‘It is not meet, in sooth,’ said Suibhne, ‘for the women to violate the Lord's fast-day;  even as the woman beats the flax,’ said he, ‘so  were my folk beaten in the battle of Magh Rath.’ He heard then the vesper-bell pealing, whereupon he said:‘Sweeter indeed were it to me to hear the voices of  the cuckoos on the banks of the Bann from every side  than the grig-graig of this bell which I hear to-  night’; and he uttered the lay:
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Sweeney came after the need of the church at Swim of the Two Birds on the Shannon, a constant hostelry of Cluain Boirenn was the fire there; on Friday was completed the ritual of the sun-chanting there. And then the clerics of the church were making the noble noon-prayer and women were offering flax and women were judging garments. ‘It is not right,’ said Sweeney, ‘for the Friday woman of the Communion to be milled. Pleasant is the appearance of the woman with the flax,’ said he, ‘and thus will my people be remembered in the battle of Mag Rath.’ He then uttered a prophecy with the sound of a harp, a secret revealed: ‘Sweeter to me,’ said he, ‘is the voice of the cuckoos to their young on the bank of the Banna than every other sound of the strings which I hear tonight,’ and he finished the song.
